moves.1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. Nf3 Nxe4 4. Nxe5: ? This is the oldest mistake in the book. Now I win a piece.
moves.5. O-O: The only move. Ng4 fails miserably after d5!
moves.5... Qxe5 6. Re1: This is an annoying pin. It would be tragic if it wasn't for...
moves.6... Bc5: ! I create a much bigger threat.
moves.7. Re2 Bxf2+: I get out of the pin.
moves.11... O-O: I get my rook closer to the action and eliminate any king side threats his queen might pose.
moves.12. d3 Qd4+: Tempting his bishop to block it...
moves.13. Be3: ? This allows a trade of queens.
moves.13... Qf6 14. Rg1: ? His idea was after the g-file was opened he would play Bh6. But that is easily defended.
moves.16. Bh6: This is a waste of a tempo.
moves.18. f4 f5: Stopping f5! and freeing my king.
moves.23... d5 24. hxg6+ Rxg6: Getting a passed pawn and pinning the knight.
moves.25. Bg5 Bd7: Getting my bishop into the action.
moves.26. Rh1 Rh8: Preparing the advance of the h-pawn.
moves.29. Ke2 h6: I start claiming the king side.
moves.30. Bh4 Rg4 31. Nh5: Threatening to fork Rook and Bishop.
moves.33. Nf6: This is an empty threat now.
moves.33... Rxf4+ 34. Kg2 Bc6+: My bishop spears the king to the rook.
moves.35... Re2+ 36. Kg3 Rg4+ 37. Kf3: I have gotten the pieces into the proper positions.
moves.37... Bxd5+ 38. Kxe2: ? He should have created a passed pawn with cxd5 and tried to advance it. This also loses a piece.
moves.40. Kf1 Nd2+: Can you tell where this knight is headed?
moves.41. Ke1 Nf3+ 42. Ke2 Ne5: His king is still pinned and the pawn is threatened.
moves.43. b4 b6 44. bxc5 bxc5 45. a4: There was nothing else to do...
